Be the spiritual mother or father of this child. Welcome it with your affection and love through a brief daily prayer for 9 months.

step1.title: Holy Rosary
step1.text: Pray one of the mysteries of the Rosary (one decade) every day for nine months.

step2.title: Special Prayer
step2.text: "Lord Jesus, I ask You for this conceived child, spiritually adopted by me, who is in danger of being killed by abortion..."

step3.title: Additional Action
step3.text: Spontaneously add a daily purpose, such as a small sacrifice or good deed.

q1.question: Who can participate in Spiritual Adoption?
q1.answer: Anyone: laypeople, religious, children, youth, and adults. All it takes is the desire to save a life through prayer.

q2.question: Can I adopt more than one child at a time?
q2.answer: The rule recommends adopting one child at a time, so that the commitment is lived with fidelity during the 9 months.

q3.question: What should I do if I forget to pray one day?
q3.answer: It is not a sin, but prolonged forgetting interrupts the Adoption. If you forget one day, continue normally the next day. If you forget for a long time, the commitment should be restarted.

q4.question: How to choose the child's name?
q4.answer: You don't need to choose a name, as God already knows them. But if you wish, you can give a symbolic name to facilitate your prayer.

We also let you know why we’re collecting it and how it will be used.
privacy.p2: We only retain collected information for as long as necessary to provide you with your requested service. What data we store, we’ll protect within commercially acceptable means to prevent loss and theft, as well as unauthorized access, disclosure, copying, use or modification.
privacy.p3: We don’t share any personally identifying information publicly or with third-parties, except when required to by law.
privacy.p4: Our website may link to external sites that are not operated by us. Please be aware that we have no control over the content and practices of these sites, and cannot accept responsibility or liability for their respective privacy policies.
privacy.p5: You are free to refuse our request for your personal information, with the understanding that we may be unable to provide you with some of your desired services.
privacy.p6: Your continued use of our website will be regarded as acceptance of our practices around privacy and personal information. If you have any questions about how we handle user data and personal information, feel free to contact us.

cookies.what_text: As is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or 'break' certain elements of the sites functionality.
cookies.how_text: We use cookies for a variety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the functionality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookies if you are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.
cookies.disable_text: You can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser (see your browser Help for how to do this). Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the functionality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain functionality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.
cookies.account: Account related cookies If you create an account with us then we will use cookies for the management of the signup process and general administration. These cookies will usually be deleted when you log out however in some cases they may remain afterwards to remember your site preferences when logged out.
cookies.login: Login related cookies We use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.
cookies.newsletter: Email newsletters related cookies This site offers newsletter or email subscription services and cookies may be used to remember if you are already registered and whether to show certain notifications which might only be valid to subscribed/unsubscribed users.

These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.
cookies.forms: Forms related cookies When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.
cookies.preferences: Site preferences cookies In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the functionality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.

what_is_page.title: What is Spiritual Adoption?
what_is_page.intro_p1: Spiritual Adoption is the exercise of spiritual motherhood and fatherhood with children threatened by abortion. Imagine that somewhere that only God knows, a child has emerged who is not being expected. When the parents discover its existence, they will be frightened and consider abortion as a solution. Be the spiritual mother or father of this child. Welcome it with your affection and love through a brief daily prayer for 9 months.
what_is_page.intro_p2: One of the benefits of Spiritual Adoption is the happy conviction that a human being, desired by God and sent to this world to fulfill their mission, is being saved. Thus, spiritual mothers and fathers feel the happiness of giving their free love to a child and its mother and feel perfectly aligned with God, the source of all life.

manifesto.title: Spiritual Adoption - A manifestation of authentic and palpable love in favor of life.
manifesto.p1: At the base of our Christian life we have the commandment of love. In it God is reminding us that we cannot be indifferent towards our neighbor. In today's world, our most vulnerable brothers are the unborn, threatened by abortion, as they cannot defend themselves alone. It is our mission to save them from this threat.
manifesto.p2: Most of the time abortion is presented as a totally safe procedure that does not harm the woman's health. The real dangers of performing abortion and the existence of post-abortion syndrome are hidden. For love of women, we need to make them aware and offer them the necessary support so they never choose abortion as a solution in the case of an unwanted pregnancy.
manifesto.p3: Through Spiritual Adoption, we can effectively protect the child and help its mother.

child_gesture.title: Gesture of love for the child
child_gesture.p1: Spiritual Adoption, first of all, defends the life of the child, threatened by abortion. The tradition of the Catholic Church has always considered human life as something that must be protected and favored in all stages of its existence. Honest science, which takes into account known scientific data and simple logic, recognizes conception as the beginning of a new life, the beginning of the existence of a new human being that has its own organism distinct from the father's and mother's organism, even if during the first 9 months it depends totally on the latter.
child_gesture.p2: Defending an unborn child we are proving our love to it and to God who is the source of life. No matter how many times a new life arises without the intention of the parents, for God there is no error - each person is loved by Him, desired and enriched with gifts and talents to fulfill an important mission in this world.
child_gesture.p3: In the proposal of Spiritual Adoption, we are invited to care for a child threatened by abortion in the first 9 months after their conception. We believe that God, in His mercy and omnipotence, will help this child survive this most difficult moment, be welcomed and loved by their own family or by an adoptive family.
child_gesture.p4: On the other hand, we know that intentionally taking the life of any person, especially an unborn child, is an unacceptable and unnecessary act. As much as the child's mother may not have the conditions to guarantee the future of her child, there are many initiatives that aim to help the mother during pregnancy and there are also many families who dream of adopting a child and giving them a home and much love.

mother_gesture.title: Gesture of love for the mother
mother_gesture.p1: The prayer of Spiritual Adoption not only protects the life of the child facing the threat of abortion, but also protects the child's mother from the various consequences that may arise after the procedure. Abortion advocates often portray it as a safe and risk-free procedure when performed with proper medical assistance. However, this is far from true. Medicine recognizes several physical and psychological complications associated with abortion. According to Dr. Maurício Price, the serious consequences of abortion are always present, whether performed legally or clandestinely.
mother_gesture.p2: Furthermore, it is important to highlight that in research involving women who faced complications after abortion:
mother_gesture.bullet1: More than 90% reported that they did not receive adequate information to make an informed decision.
mother_gesture.bullet2: More than 80% stated that they probably would not have opted for abortion if they had not been strongly encouraged by third parties, including abortion counselors.
mother_gesture.bullet3: 83% mentioned that they would have decided to carry the pregnancy forward if they had received support from their partners, families, or other significant people in their lives.

physical_consequences.title: Physical consequences:
physical_consequences.text: Medical scientists point to the following complications: cervical laceration, which can result in subsequent premature births; uterine perforation; risk of infertility; danger of damage to the intestines, tubes and bladder; removal of the uterus (hysterectomy) and/or the endometrium (mucosa); ectopic pregnancy; introduction of saline solution into the mother's bloodstream; and maternal death, regardless of the abortion method.

psychological_consequences.title: Psychological consequences:
psychological_consequences.p1: Psychologists and psychiatrists point to the following disorders as the most frequent: flashbacks of the moment of abortion; hysterical crises; feelings of guilt; visions or dreams with the aborted child; difficulty in maintaining and developing interpersonal relationships; anxiety and fear of another pregnancy; drop in self-esteem due to the destruction of one's own child; depression; and nine times more propensity to suicide.
psychological_consequences.p2: Studies show that women who abort have a set of psychological symptoms that occur much more frequently than among women who do not. These symptoms include flashbacks (63%), suicide attempts (28%), hysterical attacks (51%), loss of self-confidence and self-esteem (82%), eating disorders such as anorexia or bulimia (39%), illegal drug use (41%) and loss of pleasure during sexual intercourse (59%).
psychological_consequences.p3: Abortion is related to increased depression, violent behavior, alcohol and drug abuse, replacement pregnancy and reduced maternal bonding with children born later. These factors are closely associated with child abuse and seem to confirm individual clinical assessment linking post-traumatic abortion with mistreatment.
psychological_consequences.p4: A study with 1,000 women, to discover the differences between female adolescents who had given birth and those who had practiced abortion in the face of an unexpected pregnancy, found that adolescents who proceeded to abortion expressed five times more need for psychological help than those who had their children. The researcher states that 'being a mother in adolescence is inevitably an experience that implies difficulties, but the occurrence of psychological problems with the practice of abortion is much higher than with carrying the pregnancy forward'.

spiritual_consequences.title: Spiritual consequences:
spiritual_consequences.p1: The Catholic Church clearly addresses, in several documents, the value of human life from conception to natural death. It highlights the need to protect it and emphasizes the gravity of the act of abortion, both for the women who practice it and for those who collaborate with such practices.
spiritual_consequences.p2: This perspective finds its basis in the fifth commandment of God, which warns us against any action, word, thought or omission that results in the loss of the life of another human being. According to this view, whoever kills or collaborates with the death of their neighbor is in opposition to God, who is the source of life, not death. Thus, beyond the evil committed against the other, the aggressor or collaborator of this aggression harms themselves and their own history.
spiritual_consequences.p3: The injustice of murder is recognized not only by those who believe, but by every human being who preserves mental health and does not let themselves be seduced by inhuman ideologies. Hence the reason why most countries include the right to life as fundamental and inalienable in their constitutions.
spiritual_consequences.p4: The person who practices or collaborates with abortion seriously compromises their relationship with God and their neighbor. This entails serious spiritual consequences, going beyond the temporal dimension. Therefore, by defending the life of the unborn, we are not only protecting the child threatened by abortion, but also their mother and all other people involved, from the spiritual implications of this act.
spiritual_consequences.citations_intro: Here are some quotes from Church documents that address this theme.

donum_vitae.title: INSTRUCTION ON RESPECT FOR HUMAN LIFE IN ITS ORIGIN AND ON THE DIGNITY OF PROCREATION from the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, Donum vitae:
donum_vitae.quote1: 'The inviolability of the right to life of the innocent human being « from the moment of conception until death »,[14] is a sign and a requirement of the very inviolability of the person to whom the Creator has granted the gift of life.' (Donum vitae n. 4)
donum_vitae.quote2: 'The fruit of human generation, from the first moment of its existence, that is, from the moment the zygote has been formed, demands the unconditional respect that is morally due to the human being in his bodily and spiritual totality. The human being is to be respected and treated as a person from the moment of conception; and therefore from that same moment his rights as a person must be recognized, among which in the first place is the inviolable right of every innocent human being to life.' (Donum vitae n. 5,1)

gaudium_et_spes.title: PASTORAL CONSTITUTION ON THE CHURCH IN THE MODERN WORLD, GAUDIUM ET SPES:
gaudium_et_spes.quote: 'God, the Lord of life, has entrusted to men the noble duty of safeguarding life, and they should carry it out in a manner worthy of themselves. Life must be protected with the utmost care from the moment of conception: abortion and infanticide are abominable crimes.' (Gaudium et Spes, n. 51)

catechism.title: CATECHISM OF THE CATHOLIC CHURCH:
catechism.p2271: 2271. Since the first century the Church has affirmed the moral evil of every procured abortion. This teaching has not changed and remains unchangeable. Direct abortion, that is, abortion willed either as an end or a means, is gravely contrary to the moral law.
catechism.p2272: 2272. Formal cooperation in an abortion constitutes a grave offense. The Church attaches the canonical penalty of excommunication to this crime against human life. 'A person who procures a completed abortion incurs excommunication latae sententiae' (Canon Law 1398), by the very commission of the offense and subject to the conditions provided by Canon Law. The Church does not thereby intend to restrict the scope of mercy. Rather, she makes clear the gravity of the crime committed, the irreparable harm done to the innocent who is put to death, as well as to the parents and the whole of society.

family_gesture.title: GESTURE OF LOVE FOR THE FAMILY
family_gesture.p1: Spiritual adoption also benefits the family of the child whom we spiritually adopt.
family_gesture.p2: The natural place for a new life to arise is in the family. Therefore, the welcoming of a new life is intrinsically linked with what the family is in its essence. From the family we expect love, welcoming, affection, security, intimacy in relationships and the knowledge of our roots.
family_gesture.p3: The child has the right to be welcomed by their parents and other family members. Thus being inserted into a structure that is capable of guaranteeing for them everything that a human being needs for good psychological, spiritual and social development. On the other hand, the conceived child is for the members of the family: 'the son', 'the brother', 'the grandchild', 'the nephew', etc. By denying the right to be born to this child, the family strikes itself and in a certain way its future generations.
family_gesture.p4: Through the daily prayer of spiritual adoption, we are protecting the family of the child for whom we pray, from the consequences of abortion and ensuring that it is healthy in its structure, in its relationships, in its current and future context.

history.title: How did Spiritual Adoption arise?
history.p1: The beginning of Spiritual Adoption is associated with the apparitions of Our Lady at Fatima. In her messages Mary asked us to pray the Rosary and do penance in reparation for the sins that most offend God. We have no doubt that one of the sins that most saddens and offends God is abortion.
history.p2: Embracing Mary's request, the 'Blue Army of Our Lady of Fatima' movement, founded in 1947 in the USA, launched the purpose of prayer for children threatened by abortion.
history.p3: The Archdiocese of Rio de Janeiro presented the proposal of Spiritual Adoption on October 8, 2020, as a concrete gesture to end that year's National Life Week, whose theme was 'Life, gift and commitment'.

famosos.title: 9 famous people who escaped abortion
famosos.intro: They were found by abortion; but because they escaped and had the opportunity to be born, they could realize other talents.
famosos.p1: We all have the right to be born; no matter how many mistakes someone may make, there is always a greater reason for that person to exist. It is always worth letting everyone perform their own show on this earth! Bearing this in mind, it is almost impossible to believe that the famous people below were almost not born. If that were the case, the world would not be the same without them!

jobs.title: Steve Jobs
jobs.text: Can you imagine your life without a Mac, iPhone or iPad? If Joanne Schieble, then 22, had given up on carrying her pregnancy to term, technology would not be as we know it today. Joanne, Steve Jobs' biological mother, got pregnant by her Syrian boyfriend and decided to put the baby up for adoption. She chose a family financially capable paying for the baby's college studies, but when the prospective parents found out Joanne was expecting a boy, they backed out because they wanted a girl. Joanne, about to give birth and with no time to look for a new family, eventually agreed to hand her son over to a humble couple. Jobs, in an interview, stated he was grateful for not having ended up in an abortion.

bieber.title: Justin Bieber
bieber.text: In her book “Nowhere But Up”, Pattie Mallette, Justin Bieber's mother, says that when she found herself pregnant at 17, she was pressured to have an abortion. But that was never an option: “I knew I couldn't do that,” she revealed in an interview. “The only thing I knew was that I had to keep the pregnancy. I didn't know how I was going to do it, but I just knew I couldn't abort,” she said. At 18, Pattie gave birth to Justin in Ontario (Canada) and raised him with the help of her parents Bruce and Diane, the singer's grandparents.

bolanos.title: Roberto Gómez Bolaños
bolanos.text: In a brief commercial in Mexico, Roberto Gómez Bolaños (known in Brazil for his acting as Chavo and Chapulín), revealed that when his mother was pregnant she suffered an accident where she almost died. The doctors then recommended she abort. “Abort, me? Never!” replied the mother. “She defended life, my life. It is thanks to her that I am here,” he stated.

boyle.title: Susan Boyle
boyle.text: When Bridget Boyle, at 45, got pregnant, doctors considered it a high-risk pregnancy and therefore advised her to abort. “But that was unthinkable for my mother, a devout Catholic. I am only here because she had faith,” said the British woman. During childbirth, an emergency C-section, Susan suffered lack of oxygen and was born underweight. Therefore, doctors told her mother: “Susan will never amount to anything, don't expect much from her.” In her autobiography, Susan said doctors shouldn't have made that comment. “What they didn't know is that I'm a fighter and have tried all my life to prove them wrong”. Susan Boyle gained international attention during a performance on the show “Britain's Got Talent”. Her first album “I Dreamed a Dream” (2009) broke sales records in the UK and totaled nearly 14 million copies sold worldwide. Susan won two Grammys and is known for supporting charitable causes.

ronaldo.title: Cristiano Ronaldo
ronaldo.text: When Maria Dolores discovered she was pregnant for the fourth time, she sought a doctor to perform an abortion. He, however, replied that there was no physical reason to abort and that this baby would bring her much joy in life. Without the doctor's complicity, Dolores tried other abortion methods that didn't work. Finally, she said “if God's will is for this child to be born, so be it!” During childbirth, the same doctor said a phrase that stayed forever in Dolores' memory: “With feet like these, he will be a soccer player!” In other consultations, the doctor seeing the mother's concern, encouraged her saying: “Rejoice, woman, this baby will bring you much luck in life and much happiness!” Cristiano is today the number 7 shirt for the Spanish club Real Madrid and is considered the greatest Portuguese soccer player of all time.

dion.title: Celine Dion
dion.text: The Canadian singer's mother was devastated to learn she was expecting Celine, her 14th child, and told a priest she intended to have an abortion; the priest then convinced her not to do it and to accept the baby. “I owe my life to this priest,” said the singer. “When my mother got over the disappointment, she didn't waste time on self-pity and loved me as passionately as my younger brother,” she declared.

bocelli.title: Andrea Bocelli
bocelli.text: When his mother was pregnant, she was hospitalized with appendicitis. Due to the treatment, doctors advised her to abort because the baby could be born with disabilities. Even so, the young mother refused and gave birth to Andrea Bocelli, who was born with a voice capable of moving audiences around the world.

silva.title: Thiago Silva
silva.text: Dona Angela, mother of soccer player Thiago Silva, said she thought about abortion. “I even cried on my father's lap saying I didn't want to have the abortion, but that I also couldn't afford to raise another child. But he wouldn't let me do that, commit a sin!”, said the mother. Of humble origin, Thiago grew up in the Santa Cruz favela, in the West Zone of Rio de Janeiro. Today, Dona Angela's youngest is considered one of the best (and most expensive) defenders in the world.

nicholson.title: Jack Nicholson
nicholson.text: At 17, June Frances Nicholson, despite being pressured by colleagues to abort, gave birth to a baby she named Jack. June left her son with her parents, John and Ethel, and the boy grew up believing his grandparents were his parents and June was his sister. Only after his mother's death did Nicholson discover his own story. “My only emotion is gratitude, literally, for my life. If June and Ethel had less character, I would never have lived. These women gave me the gift of life,” he said.

padre_pio.title: Padre Pio made a woman see the Pope she aborted
padre_pio.intro: "The child you killed in your womb with abortion, in God's designs, was meant to become this pope."
padre_pio.p1: In the life of St. Padre Pio of Pietrelcina there is this beautiful and interesting episode.
padre_pio.p2:
To a woman who went to his confessional, Padre Pio said:
“Close your eyes and tell me what you see.”
padre_pio.p3: The lady obeyed, closed her eyes and said: “I see a huge square with many people. Among the people, I see a procession moving solemnly. I see in the cloudy many priests, bishops and cardinals: all precede a pope who is taking the throne. Yes, I see precisely a pope on the throne (it was the gestatorial chair) and a large crowd cheering this pope, very beautiful … But what does all this mean?”
padre_pio.p4: Padre Pio replied: “The child you killed in your womb with abortion, in God's designs, was meant to become this pope”.
padre_pio.p5: The poor woman screamed and fainted beside the confessional.
padre_pio.source: (Taken from: E. Boninsegna, Ero curato, ora sono da curare, Verona, Professional Manuscript, 2019, page 139).

matheus.title: Moving testimony of a Priest who was almost aborted
matheus.intro: Testimony of Father Matheus Aquino, from the Archdiocese of São Sebastião do Rio de Janeiro.
matheus.p1: Father Matheus Aquino shares with deep humility and gratitude the miracle of his own life. In a touching account, he reveals how close he came to not being born, but how God's hand and his mother's courageous decision changed the destiny of his existence and led him to the priesthood.
matheus.p2: "I am the fruit of a 'yes' to life. If today I am a priest, if today I can serve the brothers and celebrate the Eucharist, it is because someone believed that my life had infinite value from conception."
matheus.p3: His story is a beacon of hope for so many mothers who, in moments of despair and uncertainty, consider abortion as the only way out. Father Matheus' testimony is a living reminder that we never know the wonders God has in store for every child He allows to be conceived.
matheus.p4: Watch the video above to hear the full account of this priest from Rio de Janeiro who today dedicates his life to proclaiming the Gospel of Life.

melissa.title: Her grandmother forced her mother to abort, but she survived
melissa.intro: In the eighth month of pregnancy she was forced to abort against her will. But the child growing in her womb had a purpose in life, beyond death.
melissa.p1: In the eighth month of pregnancy, a 19-year-old college student from Ohio (United States) was forced to abort against her will. But the child growing in her womb had a purpose in life, beyond death.
melissa.p2: The abortion was unsuccessful and a girl named Melissa was born. However, the newborn had to face another challenge.
melissa.p3: When an aborted child is born alive, abortionists are obliged to deny medical assistance so that it dies alone. But on this occasion a nurse defied this order and took Melissa to the hospital to receive proper care.
melissa.p4: Melissa weighed only two pounds and suffered from severe respiratory problems, doctors said she would have a life full of complications and there was no hope for her future.
melissa.p5: However, Melissa was adopted by a family who fought for her life. When she turned 14, her adoptive family explained to her that she was adopted. This news caused a radical change in her life.
melissa.p6: A new world of questions came to her mind: “I was surprised when my parents told me I was adopted. Who was my biological mother then? What were my roots? Where did I come from?”, she acknowledges.
melissa.p7: With so many unanswered questions, over the next few years the young woman began investigating adoption papers and medical records looking for clues that would lead her to her biological mother.
melissa.p8: After a long time struggling with bureaucratic hurdles, she discovered a truth that hid many secrets:
melissa.p9: “I discovered I had survived an abortion, but the story got complicated and as I investigated, I came across the harsh reality,” says Melissa.
melissa.p10: In fact, Melissa's biological mother had been forced to abort. The most surprising part of this story is knowing who forced her and committed this crime: Melissa's grandmother, a “nurse” who worked at a place that performed abortions and didn't hesitate to organize everything to kill her own granddaughter before birth, in the eighth month of pregnancy.
melissa.p11: Her grandmother's cruelty knew no bounds. Upon discovering the baby had survived the abortion, she left her in a room to die alone. It was the kindness of another nurse that saved her. Without the grandmother noticing, she called an ambulance to transfer the newborn to a hospital.
melissa.p12: But there was a second secret in this story, Melissa's biological mother didn't know her daughter had survived the abortion. She was told she had died and for all those years had lived tormented by having killed her baby.
melissa.p13: When Melissa learned the terrible story of her birth, she experienced a struggle within herself. “I didn't want to tell anyone, I was ashamed and at the same time angry, I lived desolate for years because of it. But I realized that if I didn't tell, my biological mother would never know I was alive,” she tells Fox News.
melissa.p14: It took several years to experience true forgiveness. Thanks to her Christian faith she managed to overcome the trauma of her birth, even managing to get in touch with her biological mother.
melissa.p15: “Now I know my grandmother wanted to change my destiny so I wouldn't be in the world. For some reason, my birth and adoption were a secret to everyone. But I can't keep this secret anymore. I want to tell my story to help save millions of babies who are aborted every year. I want to help mothers make the decision to bet on their children's lives,” continues Melissa.
melissa.p16: Abortion is a human rights issue, which is why this survivor is part of the pro-life movement in the United States.
melissa.p17: “I once read a statistic that said every abortion affects seven people, not just the mother, but the father, grandparents, siblings... If 58 million abortions were performed in the last 44 years, that equals at least 406 million people who suffered the consequences of an abortion”.
melissa.p18: Thus, Melissa launched a message of encouragement to the pro-life community that is being persecuted. “To people who mock and ridicule human life I can only show love, we can love people, but not share their way of thinking, even if they don't believe life has unique value,” she states.
melissa.p19: Melissa also criticized Planned Parenthood, the leading abortion provider in the United States. “I am sure if they had taken my mother to abort at the Planned Parenthood center I wouldn't have survived: there is no mercy there. And even if I had survived the abortion, they would do everything so I wouldn't be alive,” she sentences.
melissa.p20: Now, Melissa Ohden is the author of several books in which she speaks about forgiveness and the meaning of life. In addition, she created the website “The Abortion Survivors”, a community so that people who survived an abortion can find psychological and social help.
melissa.p21: In her personal life, Melissa formed her own family. She is the mother of two daughters and the eldest, Olivia, was born in the same hospital where she was cared for after surviving the abortion.

tong.title: Man has already adopted over 100 children who would have been aborted
tong.intro: Vietnamese Tong Phuoc Phuc is another wonderful example of real-life heroes! If it weren't for him, over a hundred children would have been aborted in his country.
tong.p1: Vietnamese Tong Phuoc Phuc is another wonderful example of real-life heroes! If it weren't for him, over a hundred children would have been aborted in his country. Yes, he is the father of dozens of children who might never have been born.
tong.p2: This love story began in 2001, when Phuc's wife was pregnant and had many complications. During the delivery, which was extremely difficult, Phuc saw that many of the women entering the nearby room left there without their babies.
tong.p3: He didn't really understand why at first. Only later did Phuc realize the children had been aborted, upon seeing doctors throwing fetuses in the trash. Phuc was moved by what he saw and asked to take the bodies home.
tong.p4: With a humble life, he gathered all his savings from his work as a builder to buy a field where he could bury the remains of the babies that were thrown in the trash. Phuc's wife found it all very strange at first, to the point of thinking her husband had gone mad. Even so, he continued and today, over 10,000 fetuses rest in peace in the field bought by him.
tong.p5: Since then, mothers who aborted children visit the cemetery to pray for their children. In addition, pregnant women at risk of abortion began to seek Phuc for help. He then opened the doors of his home to receive them and offered to adopt the babies they couldn't raise.
tong.p6: Phuc keeps the little ones until the mothers are able to take care of them on their own.
tong.subtitle: Names with Meaning
tong.p7: The boys adopted by him are named Vihn (meaning “Honor”), and the girls are named Tam (meaning “Heart”). The second name is always the mother's or her city of origin - in case the mother returns to pick her up.
tong.p8: The surname is Phuc himself, as he considers everyone as if they were his children. Phuc says “these children now have a safe home. I am willing to help and teach them to be good people”.
tong.p9: Caring for over a hundred children is not an easy task, but Phuc doesn't intend to stop here. He declared he will continue “this work until my last breath of life, and I encourage my children to continue helping other underprivileged people”.

participate_page.title: How to Participate?
participate_page.intro: Participation in Spiritual Adoption begins with the intention of spiritually caring for a child known only to God, threatened by abortion, their mother, and their family. We express this intention through the prayer that initiates Spiritual Adoption.

start_prayer.title: Initial Prayer
start_prayer.text: Mary, Most Holy Virgin, Mother of God, and all the angels and saints, I (your name), guided by the desire to collaborate in the defense of the unborn, today, on (date), firmly decide to spiritually adopt a child whose name is known only to God, and I promise for nine months, every day, to pray in defense of their life, and so that in the future they may become a worthy and honest person. Amen.

commitment.title: Daily Commitment
commitment.intro: From this moment on, your commitment to Spiritual Adoption is to pray daily, for 9 months, one mystery of the rosary (1 Our Father and 10 Hail Marys) and the following prayer:
commitment.prayer: Lord Jesus, through the intercession of Mary, Your Mother, who welcomed You with love, and through the intercession of Saint Joseph, a man of trust who cared for You after birth, I ask You for this conceived child, spiritually adopted by me, who is in danger of being aborted. Give their mother and other family members the love and courage to let them live, You, who granted them life. Amen.

end_prayer.title: Closing Prayer
end_prayer.intro: On the last day of the 9th month, ending the spiritual adoption, we can say the following prayer:
end_prayer.text: Lord Jesus, today my spiritual child was born, and I fully trust that they were welcomed with much love and affection. Bless them in all their ways. May they grow up bringing to this world the love that comes from You and the talents that will enrich humanity. Always be with them and may they never turn away from You! I thank You, Lord, for the wonderful experience of spiritual motherhood/fatherhood.
end_prayer.footer: Upon closing this spiritual adoption, we can start a new one, asking God to choose another child He knows who is at risk of being aborted. We manifest our intention to care for them spiritually through the prayer that initiates Spiritual Adoption.

who_can.title: Who can participate in Spiritual Adoption?
who_can.text: Spiritual Adoption presents itself, in its simplicity, as an initiative open to everyone: laity, consecrated persons, men, women, people of all ages (with children being accompanied by their parents).

recommendations.title: Who do we recommend Spiritual Adoption for?

aborto.title: For people who have committed abortion
aborto.p1: Women who have gone through the experience of abortion, especially those who were not fully aware of the evil they were practicing or who felt pressured by the child's father, family, or dramatic circumstances in which the child was conceived, find a welcome in God's Mercy when they join Spiritual Adoption. Taking concrete actions in defense of life, such as through the practice of Spiritual Adoption, brings comfort to women, restoring inner peace and healing wounded hearts.
aborto.p2: Merciful God, in forgiving the act of abortion, expects that women and their families involved in this sin never commit it again. However, it is not just this that God expects; He also longs for the conversion of hearts. In practice, this means understanding the right to life from conception until natural death, being aware of the gravity of the sin of abortion, and engaging in the defense of life, especially of children who are at risk of being aborted.

idosos.title: For the elderly
idosos.p1: Spiritual Adoption provides the elderly, who often experience loneliness and a sense of uselessness, with a renewed sense of life and suffering. In it, the elderly discover a significant mission in which they can participate, regardless of health challenges or limitations resulting from age. Spiritual Motherhood and Fatherhood for the elderly revives the feeling of love, as they realize there is a life that needs care and prayer, generating greater happiness. They experience great joy in their hearts by being able to serve and help the most defenseless.

jovens.title: For young people
jovens.p1: The prayer of Spiritual Adoption generates significant fruits in the lives of young people. Many of them recognize as benefits of this commitment a strengthening in the practice of chastity, as well as a deeper understanding of their own sexuality as a gift from God.
jovens.p2: Through Spiritual Adoption, young people are preparing in a more mature way for the sacrament of marriage and to more consciously welcome the gift of children. For those young people who feel helpless in the face of the vastness of the evil of abortion, Spiritual Adoption provides a sense of responsibility and commitment to saving the lives of the most vulnerable.

criancas.title: For children
criancas.p1: For children who, with the guidance of their parents, take on the commitment of Spiritual Adoption, it becomes an exercise in spiritual maturity, making them aware of the value of life.

casais.title: For couples who cannot have their own children
casais.p1: For couples who have not yet been able to have biological children, Spiritual Adoption provides the experience of the beauty of spiritual motherhood and fatherhood. This enhances the experience of free love and, in some cases, serves as a stimulus to start the legal adoption process.

ulma.title: Ulma Family
ulma.subtitle: Blessed martyrs in defense of life
ulma.p1: At the beginning of the Second World War, Józef Ulma was a prominent citizen in the village of Markowa: librarian, photographer, active in social life and the local Catholic Youth Association. He was a fruit grower and beekeeper. His wife, Wiktoria Niemczak Ulma, was a housewife. They were married on July 7, 1935, at St. Dorothy's Church in Markowa.
ulma.p2: Together they had seven children: Stanisława (Stasia), Barbara (Basia), Władysła (Władzio), Franciszek (Franio), Antoni (Antoś), Maria (Marysia) and a seventh baby who was in gestation. The tragedy that befell the Ulma family and the Jews hidden in their home became a symbol of courage and solidarity amidst the brutality of the Nazi occupation. The example of compassion and altruism demonstrated by the Ulmas remains as a testimony of the silent resistance of ordinary people in the face of terror and injustice.
ulma.p3: In 1942, the Nazis deported several Jewish families from Markowa to concentration camps as part of their anti-Semitic policy. Only those who were hidden in peasant houses survived the persecution. On the Ulma couple's farm, eight Jews found shelter: Saul Godman, a cattle dealer, and his four sons, known as Szall. Also sisters Golda Grünfeld and Layka Didner, with a daughter.
ulma.p4: Inspired by Jesus' parable of the "Good Samaritan", Józef Ulma sheltered all eight Jews in his home, secretly keeping the attic to hide from the searches of Nazi officials. They helped him with additional work while in hiding to alleviate the costs incurred. However, the Ulmas were denounced by Włodzimierz Leś, a Nazi policeman who had taken possession of the Szall family property and wanted to get rid of its rightful owners.
ulma.p5: In the early morning hours of March 24, 1944, a German police patrol from Łańcut, commanded by Lieutenant Eilert Dieken, arrived at the Ulma house, located on the outskirts of the village. The Germans surrounded the house and took the residents hostage. All eight Jews were murdered by gunshot. Subsequently, they murdered the pregnant Wiktoria and her husband in front of the residents, who were forced to watch the scene as a lesson.
ulma.p6: Later, Eilert Dieken gave the order to also kill the six children of the family with a shot to the back of the neck, as they cried upon seeing the bodies of their parents, "so that there would be no trouble with them". During the execution, Wiktoria went into labor with her seventh child, with the baby's head and chest visible between the mother's legs after the massacre.
ulma.p7: The deaths of the Jews and the Ulma family were celebrated by the Nazis with looting on the property, jokes and drinking. In January 1945, the Ulma relatives exhumed the bodies that were on the house grounds, in separate graves from those of the Jews, and buried them in the parish cemetery of Markowa. There, the tomb became a place of constant pilgrimage for devotees who venerate the family.
ulma.p8: In April 2023, the remains of the family were exhumed and moved to a side altar of the parish church of St. Dorothy in Markowa, on the occasion of the family's beatification.
ulma.beatification_p1: In 2003, the bishop of the Diocese of Pelplin, Jan Bernard Szlaga, initiated the process of beatification of 122 Polish martyrs who died during the Second World War, including only Józef and Wiktoria Ulma. In November 2016, the process conducted in the Archdiocese of Przemyśl regarding the martyrdom of Józef and Wiktoria Ulma was completed and sent to Pelplin, so that from there it would follow to the Congregation for the Causes of Saints in the Vatican.
ulma.beatification_p2: On February 20, 2017, the congregation separated the family's process from the other martyrs of Poland and designated the Archdiocese of Przemyśl alone to carry out the cause. With this, the six children of the Ulma couple were included in the process and the possibility of the martyrdom of the unborn baby. On December 17, 2022, Pope Francis recognized the family's martyrdom, motivated by hatred of the faith.
ulma.beatification_p3: On February 15, 2023, the Archdiocese of Przemyśl announced that the pontiff chose Cardinal Marcello Semeraro to represent him at the beatification ceremony, which took place in Markowa on September 10, 2023. On Sunday morning, September 10, Pope Francis recalled the witness left by the Ulma family during the Angelus prayer in St. Peter's Square:
ulma.quote: “An entire family exterminated by the Nazis on March 24, 1944, for giving refuge to some Jews who were being persecuted. To the hatred and violence that characterized that era, they opposed evangelical love. May this Polish family, which represented a ray of light in the darkness of the Second World War, be for all of us a model to be imitated in the impulse of good and in service to those who need it most.”
ulma.p9: This is the first time an entire family has been beatified and that an unborn child received the title of blessed by the Catholic Church. During the homily of the beatification mass of the Ulma family, Cardinal Semeraro highlighted the value of marital holiness and the Christian witness of the unborn child Ulma, who "without ever having pronounced a word", he said, "today the little Blessed cries out to the modern world to welcome, love and protect life, especially that of the defenseless and marginalized, from the moment of conception until natural death".
ulma.p10: The Ulma family is liturgically commemorated on July 7, since it's the date of the marriage of Józef and Wiktoria.
